info.headline: Flood Advisory issued August 07 at 4:11PM EDT until August 07 at 7:00PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 PM EDT THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Nuisance to Minor flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of western North Carolina, including the following counties, Madison, Mitchell and Yancey. * WHEN...Until 1000 PM EDT. * IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to streams and other poor-drainage areas, including farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, and golf courses. Isolated, shallow flows over roadways is possible. A few flood-prone, low-water crossings may become impassible. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 401 PM EDT, Doppler radar and rain gauges indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms is ending over the Big Laurel Creek, Shelton Laurel Creek, and lower Cane River/Nolichucky watersheds in northern Madison, Yancey, and Mitchell counties. However, over the past 60-90 minutes, 1.5 to 2.5 inches of rain have fallen, which is generating excessive runoff. Rapid small stream rises are imminent or occurring, which may result in isolated areas of nuisance to Minor flooding over low-lying areas adjacent to these small streams. Areas of greatest concern are along the lower Cane River and associated tributaries near Hunting Dale Rd and Will Higgins Rd, Lickskillet Branch near Lickskillet Rd, and Big Laurel Creek and associated tributaries near Big Laurel Rd. - An additional 0.50-1.00 inch of rainfall is possible over the next 60-90 minutes as light to moderate rain persists behind the departing thunderstorms. This may prolong stream rises and the flood threat for the next few hours. No additional heavy rainfall is expected and more significant flooding is not expected to develop. - Some locations that may experience flooding include... Burnsville, Hot Springs, Wolf Ridge, Faust, Swiss, Ramseytown, Poplar, Allenstand, Walnut, and Green Mountain. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.
